awd_titl_txt: FET: Small: Quantum-secure quantum-enhanced covert networks over generalized bosonic channels
awd_abstract_narration:
Security and privacy are of utmost importance to communications, with standard cryptography-based approaches well studied in the literature.  However, these approaches are limited to protecting the content of transmissions, which is insufficient when the detection of the transmission must be prevented in the first place. Covert, or low probability of detection/intercept (LPD/LPI) communication is thus necessary in many settings, including military operations.  At the same time, quantum methodology has been demonstrated to benefit substantially the performance of non-covert communications.  This project focuses on quantifying the fundamental improvements to security and throughput of covert communication networks offered by quantum information processing, as well as characterizing the systems for achieving these gains. Additionally, the research team mentors graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project, and engages in collaborative efforts to validate the results experimentally.
 
Covert communication has thus far been studied largely from the classical viewpoint.  This includes both the practical approaches to system design such as spread spectrum as well as the corresponding information-theoretic limits.  However, quantum, not classical, mechanics govern the fundamental laws of physics.  Leveraging quantum methodology has yielded encryption systems that are provably secure against the adversary restricted only by the laws of physics. Quantum phenomena such as entanglement have been shown to substantially improve the non-covert communication bitrate.  This project takes the quantum perspective to covertness.  It looks to determine the fundamental limits of covert communication in a networked setting that is secure against the adversary who is only subject to the laws of physics.  This assumption yields mathematically provable covertness against the most powerful adversary possible.  These limits are sought for communication under different channel conditions (including dynamic links due to platform mobility and time-varying channel conditions) and resources available to the communicating parties (including quantum processing of light).  Furthermore, transmitter and receiver structures and algorithms are being devised to achieve these limits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Traditional communications-security approaches such as cryptography and information-theoretic secrecy, including quantum key distribution (QKD), deny the adversary access to the content of the transmitted message. Covert, or low probability of detection (LPD), communication prevents detection of the transmission by the adversary in the first place. However, while provably covert systems clearly have significant applications to privacy protection, covertness imposes fundamental limits on transmissible power. In fact, covert communication is generally governed by the square root law (SRL): the number of covert bits that is reliably transmissible in n channel uses scales as square root of n. This contrasts the scaling in the traditional communication that is linear in n. The low power and non-standard scaling challenges the development of both the fundamental limits of covert systems as well as their practical realizations.

The project outcomes address the intellectual meris of this project as follows:

1)      Fundamental limits of point-to-point quantum-secure quantum-enhanced covert communication: We derived the SRL and determined exactly the constant in front of sqrt(n) for quantum-secure covert communications over both the discrete-variable and continuous-variable (bosonic) classical-quantum channels. Furthermore, we characterized the covert communication benefit of shared entanglement for depolarizing and bosonic channels.  We found that entanglement assistance in both cases yields a log n factor improvement over the unassisted SRL scaling, which translates to a substantial gain in the volume of reliably transmissible covert information.

2)      Transceiver structures for bosonic covert communication: We developed optimal joint-detection receiver (JDR) structures for bosonic channel settings that employ entanglement in the form of shared two-mode squeezed vacuum (TMSV) state to achieve logarithmic gain above. Specifically, we leverage a continuous-variable pre-shared entanglement generated (e.g., from a downconversion source), binary phase modulation, and non-Gaussian JDR over a code word block to achieve at least half of the entanglement-assisted covert capacity of a thermal noise lossy bosonic channel.  Furthermore, the aforesaid receiver can be modified using a front-end that uses sum-frequency generation sandwiched with dynamically-programmable in-line two-mode squeezers, and a receiver back-end that takes full advantage of the output of the receiver's front-end by employing a non-destructive multimode vacuum-or-not measurement to achieve the entanglement-assisted classical communications capacity.

3)      We characterized the performance of single-hop quantum-secure covert networks.  Specifically, we derived the covert capacity envelope for covert broadcast over the generalized bosonic channel. We showed that time-division is optimal for quantum-secure covert broadcast, generalizing earlier classical results.  We also derived the capacity envelope for thermal-noise lossy bosonic multiple access channel (MAC).  We also showed that, for two-user noisy bosonic MAC, coherent states at the transmitters are capacity achieving in the limits of high and low mean input photon numbers, paving the way to obtaining the covert capacity envelope for covert bosonic MAC.

The broader impacts of this project have been significant. Our mathematical methods for analysis of the bosonic channel apply to other quantum communication problems. For example, to obtain the covert capacity envelopes for the bosonic broadcast and multiple-access channels, we developed the characterizations of the non-covert Holevo capacity envelopes for the generalized bosonic broadcast and multiple-access channels that take thermal noise into account as well as leakage of photons to the adversary. This allows for security analysis of bosonic broadcast and multiple access under other modalities, such quantum secrecy and quantum key distribution. Furthermore, we expect the mathematics developed in this project to carry over to complimentary fields: e.g., to the analysis and design of active sensing systems. Our entanglement-assisted joint-detection receiver (JDR) structure achieves the capacity of non-covert entanglement-assisted communication and solves a problem that has been open for over a decade. While desire for covertness supplies the regime of high-noise low-transmit power where the gain from entanglement assistance is most pronounced, the JDR structure developed in this project is not limited to covert systems and will benefit non-covert entanglement-assisted communications. The PIs have delivered multiple invited talks that focused on quantum-secure covert communication or included results from this project. In addition to yielding many conference and journal publications, this project has trained multiple graduate students and given undergraduate students an opportunity to participate in cutting edge research. The REU supplements to this project enabled mentoring of three undergraduate researchers, including two from underrepresented groups. These students will contribute to the ever-growing need for quantum information and quantum engineering workforce.
